comment_body.8:
Best first car with sporting potential for cheap?

Hi, I'm relatively poor and I'm looking for a first car. I need it to be very cheap, but I'd also like some style. My favourite era of cars is from the eighties right up to around 1998. My favourite car is the Toyota Sprinter Trueno. Are there any cheap, reliable cars that look close to a Trueno that I could possibly get for under £3000? I can do minor work on a vehicle and would use it simply as a daily driver, but I'd also be interested in upgrading it under the hood to run on a track. I would probably want a Petrol, Manual car which is preferably 4WD or RWD. I live in the UK, so I think this'll be difficult. I also need cheap insurance. So far I've considered a 1994 Toyota Corolla and have also looked at some '90s VW Golfs, VW Jettas, Vauxhall Astras and Ford Escorts. Please send advice.

comment_body.16:
Location: Southern California

Price Range: N/A, less is kinda better (see below) but ambivalent.

Lease or buy: Buy

Type of vehicle: Convertible

Must haves: Bluetooth to play music

Transmission : Auto

Intended use: daily

Vehicles considered: see below

Doing own work: No

Notes:

30 year old in Southern California looking for my next daily driver convertible. Previously I had an m235i. I've gone back and forth and it seems there is no perfect car, but the below are the cars I've considered - trying to keep it on the more modern end than going 10+ years back. My commute is currently non-existent, but when offices do open back up I don't anticipate mine being more then 20 minutes.

I was originally kinda set on getting an S2k, but my wife (1) hates how small the car is (this includes the Miatas - we walked past an ND Miata yesterday and I told her I was considering it and she gave me a Michael Scott NOOOO) and (2) would not learn how to drive manual. So, having a car that she can't drive is not really feasible. With that in mind, the Miatas I'm considering would be automatic.

Second, the car can't be too wide. We have a smaller 2 car garage and we can fit another car (for reference my wife has a Corolla), but it will certainly need to be on the smaller side. The below cars should all fit, but the wider it gets (e.g. the IS 350C) the tighter the fit.

Finally, budget. Money is not an issue - however, it's something I'm really considering because I love, love the LC 500 drop top. Obviously I'm not gonna go out and buy a $100k car, but I'm eyeing it in a few years. I figure the cheaper car I get, the more I can justify socking away money for the LC 500.

NC3 Miata GT (PHRT optional)

Pros: Cheapest of the bunch, PHRT is nice but not necessary. Can get one very lightly used.

Cons: Oldest technology, price actually isn't that great compared to an ND1, size/space (downside to all Miatas - can't have a golf bag and a passenger), would likely need to upgrade stereo.

ND1 Miata GT (not RF)

Pros: Most modern (other than the ND2), has all the creature comforts, prices are dropping since the ND2 killed it - I've seen some under $20k.

Cons: ND2 is by all accounts better, still need to upgrade stereo for Apple CarPlay, I test drove one a few years ago and bought an m235i instead

ND2 Miata GT (not RF)

Pros: Newest, most modern of the bunch. Extra HP is nice in the upper band, but otherwise reports are that it doesn't make a huge difference.

Cons: Price, hasn't depreciated as much as all the other cars, still need to pay for CarPlay if you don't get a 2020.

IS 350C w/ F-Sport package

Pros: Quality interior, has room for a golf bag and a passenger, F-Sport package will make me feel slightly less like I need a hip replacement to drive it.

Cons: Outdated infotainment (classic Lexus), my sister's mother in law drives one, F-Sport is very, very hard to find, price. It's as old as the NC3, but costs $10k+ more.

I also know there's the Infiniti G37, but I'm extremely skeptical of Infiniti quality. I know the powertrain is good and reliable, but I don't have a lot of faith in Infiniti for all the other bits, including quality of the interior.

comment_body.22:
Location: Atlantic Seaboard - Washington, DC area

Price Range: $15-30k

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or Used: Either, probably used

Type: Sedan, Small SUV, Hatchback

Must Have: Audio input (preferably USB, though AUX is fine if nothing else), easy to maintain, decent gas mileage (doesn’t have to be great, just not unreasonable), reliable

Transmission: Auto Preferred, but I do know how to drive manual

Intended use: Weekender with ability to be a daily driver on occasion

Vehicles considered: Sevoral Subarus (WRX), Toyota’s (RAV4, Camry, etc) and Fords (fusion, Escape)

First Vehicle: No, Owned a 2003 Toyota Camry since 2007, until it died 6 months ago

Warranty: No

Minor work: Can do fluids, oil changes, spark plugs, tires, filters, bulb changes, and other very basic work

Major work: No/see notes

Notes: Old beater died in February, basically right before pandemic. Started looking for replacement prior to lockdown, but when WFH started I kinda fell off it. Now looking to start back on the search.

Looking for a reliable car that I can keep for 5+ years, ideally (obviously no guarantees). Mainly for daily driving-like activities and the occasional longer trip.

My father is an ex-mechanic, and is very capable of major work and is willing to help as long as I am in the DC area, but I am likely to move semi-long distance within the next year for work, so while I can do most basic work on my own, I don’t feel comfortable with most major (transmission, engine, etc) work.

I do enjoy listening to music as I drive, and would prefer a vehicle with inputs to connect a phone, prioritizing USB over Aux.

Open to a new vehicle within my budget, but feel like a somewhat newer used vehicle (2015+) with reasonable miles is a better financial decision.

comment_body.31:
Turning to reddit because I'm in limbo, I'm thinking of moving from my 2018 Fiesta ST to a new Mustang ecoboost (unsure of transmission or HiPo package). I'm a dealer employee, so I get D-plan pricing (roughly 3k off msrp). My car was evaluated at what I owe (break even). This is not priority, but I was curious on what my car is worth in trade thanks to a recent orange GT with performance package on trade.

I'm on the line because I do have a '66 Mustang I'm in the process of rebuilding, but will not be as reliable as a new car and cannot afford what I really want to do to it to modernize it. Price isn't a huge issue for what I have optioned ($24k-28k before tax, etc.) and at my current APR though my credit union would be paying $425-$475 depending on loan term.

I do want to move on because I originally wanted a Focus ST, but wasn't in position to buy one. The Fiesta is nice, but lacks some comfort (seats are meh, no usable arm rest, transmission is oddly geared, cheap interior, a/c isn't that great above 95*f). Its fun to drive, but I think I was expecting more originally.

I wouldn't be buying immediately, more likely waiting for end of year deals. I just want to hear what someone else has to say besides myself :)

Reliable, durable, not too terrible on gas, and cheap to buy parts for if needed.

Thanks in advance 😇

What's a good car for city & highway driving with beefy suspension/ wheels (BAD city roads, so no sleek/ sports cars) with good stop-go & merging acceleration?

-Buy

Thoughts??

Hello all, I posted this already, but it got removed quickly since I'm supposed to post it here. I'm not going to use the template because it's stupid. I've already made what I'm looking for concise enough.

My priorities for a car in order: reliability, MPG, handling, comfort, safety, and finally power.

I've looked into the Prius, the Ioniq (I really like the Ioniq but I'm told prius is more reliable.), The Versa, the Elantra, the Mirage etc. I'm thinking hybrids may not be reliable enough in general? What cars would you guys buy if you had my priorities. Also, I'm thinking of using it to deliver food with door dash, if that changes anything. I'd like to be able to take the car into over 200k miles without having to replace a lot of expensive things.
